title: What in the World Does Sleep Have to Do With Managing Diabetes?

content: Do you ever feel sluggish during the day, craving food at odd times, and struggling to get a good night's sleep? Or perhaps you routinely indulge in something sweet just before bedtime, only to wake up in the middle of the night, unable to return to sleep? If so, you're not alone. As someone who battled with being overweight and was once diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, I can testify to the profound impact sleep has on managing diabetes and overall well-being.

Overweight and obesity are contributing factors in developing type 2 diabetes. While it doesn't guarantee that everyone carrying excess weight like I did will develop diabetes, there's overwhelming evidence linking the two. Alongside lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise, addressing sleep is a crucial but often overlooked aspect of diabetes care.

When I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at 268 pounds in August 2020, it became evident that my size and lack of adequate sleep were negatively affecting my health. Late-night eating had become a habit, and I would often wake up in the middle of the night to eat snacks like peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, Pop-Tarts, or cereal and drink fruit juice or soda. My normal bedtime was around 2 a.m., and I would wake up around 6 a.m., leaving me with only 4 hours of sleep.

content: Sleep-deprived people are more likely to engage in late-night snacking, often choosing high-carb snacks, and studies show they eat snacks with twice as much fat as those who get sufficient sleep.

I later learned that without enough sleep, the body struggles to function properly, leading to health issues affecting the heart, kidneys, blood, brain, and mental health. Research has shown that sleep deficiency is linked to numerous consequences, including mood changes, anxiety, depression, poor memory, poor focus, a weakened immune system, weight gain, high blood pressure, insulin resistance, and an increased risk of chronic diseases like diabetes and heart disease. No wonder why I gained so much weight and had health challenges.

content: Picture this: You're driving a car on a long road trip. Your vehicle represents your body and the road symbolizes your journey to better health. Now imagine that you've been running on only a few hours of sleep for several nights in a row. Your fuel tank is far from full and your body, like the car, is struggling to function optimally.

Now imagine that you've been running on only a few hours of sleep for several nights in a row. Your fuel tank is far from full and your body, like the car, is struggling to function optimally.

content: As you continue driving, you start to notice signs of sleep deprivation. Your reactions are slower, much like the impaired motor function that comes with a lack of sleep. Your concentration wavers and it becomes challenging to stay focused on the road ahead. The constant craving for snacks, particularly high-carb options, mirrors the increased likelihood of making poor food choices when sleep-deprived.

Now, envision pulling over to a rest area and deciding to take a nap. In this scenario, the rest area is your commitment to getting 7-8 hours of quality sleep. As you rest, your body begins to refuel and recharge, just like your car when you fill up the tank. The rejuvenation process kicks in, repairing any wear and tear and ensuring your body is ready for the journey ahead.

Back on the road with a refreshed mind and body, you notice a significant difference. Your reactions are sharper, your focus is on point, and the cravings for unhealthy snacks have diminished. The road to managing and even reversing diabetes suddenly feels smoother and more manageable.

content: This simple analogy underscores the profound impact that adequate sleep can have on your overall well-being and diabetes management. Just as a well-rested driver navigates the road more safely, a well-rested body is better equipped to tackle the challenges of diabetes. The next time you're tempted to sacrifice sleep, remember that a good night's rest is a powerful tool in the fight to beat diabetes.

Managing diabetes involves more than just diet and exercise. Quality sleep is a fundamental pillar of overall health and plays a crucial role in weight management and diabetes control. By prioritizing good-quality sleep and making simple lifestyle changes, many people, including myself, have successfully lost weight, come off diabetes medication, and even reversed type 2 diabetes. The next time you're tempted to sacrifice rest, remember sleep does a body good.
